Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with this course compared to others you have taken was
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?
Given the course objectives, the level of intellectual challenge of the material covered was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations
What are the strengths and weaknesses of the course and how could it be improved?
What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class
Comments_List: Understanding of the energy system
The difference between Primary and Final energy.  How to calculate exergy.  How climate models work and what inputs and assumptions they usie in their models.
energy system, energy policy
Covering different topics on energy system and providing basic knowledge on various energy issues.
Deepen my understanding of the development of the energy system towards the zero carbon emissions.
Very interesting problem sets and exercises. It was great engaging with the technical side after taking many high-level classes.

This class gave me a high-level view of the energy system across scales (from HVAC to buildings to electrical grids) and knowledge domains (thermodynamics to electrical engineering to social science to policy to philosophy). This class was the best I've taken at FES.
I learned a lot about the dynamics of the energy systems around the world. The most useful tool that we learned was managing electrical load for utilities.
Good overview of energy systems
Learned about the different components of energy systems both in the U.S. and abroad - including the different ways to think about the efficiency of the system.

I gained a comprehensive understanding of energy flows, from primary to final energy, and the structure of the U.S. electricity grid. I also learned some analytical tools for evaluating the efficiency of the energy system, as well as a framework for critically thinking about the end use services that energy provides. Professor Rao also brought a very interesting perspective on international energy issues and energy poverty to the class, which informed some of our discussions and topics related to 21st century energy challenges.
Basic introduction to energy systems, coupled with some degree of quantitative skills gained through the homeworks/problem sets.
overall energy systems and how to use quantitative tools for energy-related analysis
Overview of the current economic and technical structure of world energy production; important factors regarding transitioning to a 100% renewable future.

I gained a much better understanding of energy systems overall, the importance of demand-side drivers that influence our energy needs, as well as the critical role that efficiency limits play in each component of the energy system. I strengthened my skills manipulating and using quantitative energy data. Framing energy issues through the lens of the service provided helped me consider how I think about energy-related challenges, particularly as they relate to energy access and EJ issues.
Energy demand, supply and generation.

Course starts with the fundamental concepts in energy space and rapidly builds up to examine country and worldwide systems. In general it is a great course to take to step into the world of energy and related issues such as agriculture, land use, transportation etc.
I developed knowledge of various energy systems and learned about different international energy issues.
Some modelling, overview of literature and academia on energy systems
Overview of national and global energy policy and basic understanding of the science behind energy systems.
Using online tools for energy studies, General overview of the global energy sector
How the electric sector works, the value chain of energy systems, basic financial indicators, efficiency of systems, etc.

I learned about energy systems, from the small scale to worldwide systems, and how these systems function and the many factors there are when considering energy, including renewable and non-renewable energy sources, energy efficiency, and energy system modelling.
The problem sets were the best part of the course. We applied some of the concepts covered in class, and that is already beneficial for my summer job.
An overview of different aspects of high-level energy systems
Beyond my expectation, especially in the power system
Better than expected.
very well
Help me to form a better understanding on different energy topics.
Fulfilled my expectation pretty well.
They aligned very well. I expected to get exposure to the technical structure of energy systems as well as the macro perspective and trends.
My expectations of the class were far exceeded. I felt extraordinarily supported in developing skills, intuition and knowledge outside my general study area.
They aligned quite well with what I wanted to gain from the class.
Fairly well, but there was definitely some differences from my expectations.
Met my expectations
This class exceeded my expectations -- I found it incredibly valuable and interesting.

I was pleased with how we learned about the role of energy systems in the world -- how to calculate basic energy use, how to analyze common models, and how to think about generation and use from a systems level.
More or less.
some concepts were repetitive, but overall, everything was very relevant and met my expectation of the course.
The curriculum was pretty much exactly what I was expecting. Matches very well with the syllabus.
The course aligned very well with my expectations.
Not very well.
To be honest this class is not exactly a grad level energy course. It is definitely a great introduction course.  In that sense it failed to satisfy my expectations.
good
Well
They aligned very well
Very well
I think the knowledge and insights aligned with my expectations.

The class tried to cover a large amount of content and felt at times superficial. That was disappointing given how interesting the content was. That said, the problem sets were incredibly interesting.
I learned some useful information about energy production, sale, transmission, and role with climate change.

Strength: power system

Weakness: the second half of the class is kind of simple

Some of the initial homework assignments were way too in the details and took too long to do.  Strengths: I learned a lot in this course on how to think about the full energy systems.  Weakness:  there were some overlap in material with classes that I took in the past.
Strength: broad topics
I love that field trip to the power plant. I hope there can be more interactions in class.
The lectures could be more engaging and interactive.

Professor Rao's willingness to engage student's questions, the thoughtfulness of his assignments, his encyclopedic knowledge, and his scholarship otherwise all stand out as exemplary. In all earnestness, it's hard to name specific strengths of the class since it was such a wonderful experience across the board.

Strengths:
The course tried to provide a holistic view of the energy scenario around the world and offered an international perspective.

Weaknesses:
Students could have been introduced to actual practical tools such as modeling softwares which could have had more application outside of the classroom and in the professional world

The course could definitely be more organized.  The homework assignments were definitely effective in helping me learn, but the questions were frequently unclear and needed clarification from a TA.  The final brief was also a worth-while assignment to complete, but more specific instructions would be very helpful.
I thought the strengths of the course were the lectures and guest speakers. Weaknesses were a few of the problem sets, which seemed unnecessarily repetitive/redundant.
Problem sets are insightful

Strengths: the problem sets were very thoughtfully designed and engaging; the lectures were well developed, easy to follow, and interesting; the professor and TAs were very accommodating of questions and feedback

Weaknesses: some of the readings were a bit inaccessible and they were not referenced in class as often as they could have been, creating a bit of a disincentive to actually do the readings

Improvements: I would suggest creating checkpoints for the final brief throughout the semester (topic selection, outline, etc.), to motivate students to start it early, which would ensure that people got more out of that exercise than they would if they wrote it all at the end of the semester

As it is a survey course, it is understandable that some topics will be covered a little too briefly for some students to understand. For me, the thermodynamics and heat transfer lecture left me confused. Also, when looking back at slides, it could have really helped if the equations and formulas were better labeled with the variable letters and what they represent. But this class content was very interesting. I appreciated the quantative focus, especially on the psets which were well designed to be fun and informative. The discussions about the social, economic, and political contexts were valuable. Though, I could have benefitted from a better explanation of how topics were expected to be understood for the midterm. It is great how the final brief was open to be about any fascination we had.

Lectures are quite dry and the topics were somewhat sweeping and broad. I would have preferred the class to be flipped in order to incentivize attentiveness, with short quizzes after the main lectures (similar to the structure of the physical sciences foundations course). That being said, I really appreciated the learning that occurred over the course of the problem sets.
The class is well-organized with clear themes. I wish the class utilize more multimedia and demos during class.

I wish the class had skipped some of the more basic physics concepts (W = mgh) for example, but some of the other people with different backgrounds had trouble, so maybe this is a necessary issue. Overall, the class was excellent though.

I found the earlier parts of the class related to calculating efficiency parameters and other physical characteristics of energy systems particularly challenging. This is not necessarily a weakness of the course, but it would be helpful if there could be additional resources built into the class especially for people who don't have as much of an electrical engineering or quantitative background. I also think expanding the time with which we have to work on the final brief would be helpful. Given the almost limitless range of potential topics, it might be a good idea to have students submit their ideas earlier and then work on the paper for longer. Given the breadth of the topics available, it's challenging to really say something of substance within only 10 pages. Perhaps the end results might be more useful if either the scope is narrowed a bit, or the time allotted to do research etc. is lengthened.
Very technical content. Should be simplified a bit.

Great for students who do not have strong background in energy systems if you are not afraid to spend time for the class. 

The way the course is defined makes it a surface course.

Due to the various expertises and backgrounds of the students in the class, it was difficult for the professor to find a middle ground to teach the course. For instance, some of the problem sets were engineering focused and were difficult to solve. Additionally, the problem sets were not worded in the best way and were very long.
Better wording of excel assignments - although the assignments were challenging and very good.

Overall, I greatly enjoyed this course. I gained a basic grounding in the physics and engineering behind energy systems and was exposed to a range of key topics in energy policy and markets.

Recommendations to improve:
1. The lectures did not prepare us well for the homeworks. It would have been helpful to briefly walk through examples similar to the homework assignments in class. Effectively, we relied on the TAs to teach us this material rather than the instructor.
2. Similarly, the course and homework did not prepare us well for the mid-term exam. I would create a couple of short homework exercises at the beginning specifically designed for students without a background in science/math to bring them up to speed (either required or optional but highly recommended). I recognize this may feel basic for a graduate program, but many students come in with little preparation in or recollection of electrical engineering or physics. Repetitio est mater studiorum.
The class was well- organized. Material content was very relevant and it had an international focus.
Assignments are too simple for students with technical background and a lot of the discussion class surrounds very basic mathematical concepts

The lectures were sometimes strengths- when things were explained clearly and the material felt accessible. The assignments were very challenging for me and I don't think I would've been able to do them without extensive hours working with other students and going to office hours. The course material was sometimes challenging for me as well- I came into the class with little background of energy systems and I sometimes felt a little lost in lecture. But I really did appreciate Professor Rao's perspective on global energy systems and getting what I could out of the class.
Do read the reading materials!
Be engaged.   Enjoy it!
Basic course for energy issues and help you to form foundation on energy system analysis
Homeworks are really helpful for you to understand the concepts.
Make the best of the assignments and prepare to be evaluated in the technical stuff as well as general concepts from class.
This class is a perfect introduction to the energy system for someone with little background in the subject.
Do the readings.
Take this class if you're interested in a broad overview of how energy is supplied, delivered, and consumed. Definitely a must for anyone who is energy-focused.
Spend a good amount of time on the problem sets, and work with other students/the TAs as needed -- they were some of the best learning opportunities of the class in my opinion.
Start early and work together on the problem sets. Seek help from the awesome TAs when you are stuck. This is where most of the learning occurs!
Take this class if you want to gain a big picture of energy systems at global and local level
Start on the problem sets early. They give you almost two weeks to complete them, but they can take a while to finish.
A recommended course for those interested in energy.
The term energy systems analysis  is very broad and it is not possible to cover everything in depth in just one semester. Check the syllabus before to see if it matches what you want to learn.
This course is helpful for students in a range of specializations, particularly policy, business, industrial engineering, and of course energy.
Do it!
Do not expect to gain technical (engineering) knwoledge, however the class covers many perspectives, including social perspective

I would say that if you don't know much about energy systems, you will learn a lot in the class, although there will be material that you probably won't end up understanding. I got a good basic understanding of energy systems and considerations, though I would not be confident in replicating the material that was covered on the assignments.
Its quite disjointed, hard to get an overall arc of energy systems. But there is some great learning if you piece it together.
